description:
Shifty Homepage at the Designer's Site

Shifty is a square board connection game, where the goal is to create a chain of orthogonally and/or diagonally connected stones between two opposite edges of the board.

The unique feature of Shifty is that on your turn you must either place a stone orthogonally adjacent to at least one friendly stone or you must move any friendly stone, by a chess queen's move, to any empty intersection orthogonally adjacent to fewer friendly stones than the intersection it started on.

As a result you must often forego adding a stone to the board, and instead "shoot" a stone already on the board to a strategically key spot. This sharpshooting dynamic is the source of the game's strategic interest.

Whoever is skillful enough to flick the bat off into his or her own compartment gets a star. The game ends when a player has 3 stars in his/her compartment and thus wins the game.

The rules contain also special rules for advanced players and  for young children.

Froggammon is based on the game backgammon and is designed for younger players.

The board consists of modular lily tiles. In the middle there is a large central tile connecting four paths of six lily leaves. Each of the paths is closed by a larger starting area where a player places six pieces of his colour.

The aim of the game is to hop through the water lilies and get all of your frogs to you opponents’ lily pads. On one leaf there can be multiple pawns of the same player. Another player can only put his pawn on a leaf when there is only one pawn of an opponent. In that case the pawn of the opponent has to start over from his starting tile.

The game is stored in a handy storage case with a handle.

Space station "Deep Space Nine" has been invaded by "Cardasians", and the mission is take them out. You should go to "OPS" where there are the main controls of the space station with enough attack counters to defeat "Cardasians". There you can drive it and all their systems. The winner become the Space station Commander.

Each player has a pawns and a set of "attack counters" of the same color that start at SA box at external ring. The goal is to move the pawns around the board to the "OPS" at the center of the board.

Movement is controlled by dice. During movement you should get "attack counters" entering at "Cardasian Police" boxes. All players move around the three parts of the same board, so they may capture each others pawns. Captured pawns are returned to start box ("SA"). You can only move in the same direction until you enter in a "P" box (bridge boxes). From external ring, you should use "LR" box (runebounds shuttle boxes) to go to internal ring. Then, in order to go to central laberynth, you should enter at "P1" boxes with the exact number. Whether you fail, your pawn shuold come back by central gallery to "SA" start box, and you should start the attack again!

The winner is the first player to move his pawn to "OPS" box. He shall be shuttle Commander. The second one shall be the Captain and the third one the lieutenant. Both players shall meet a minimum attack counters (4 & 3 ones).

This game has been created with the objective in mind of entertaining everyone from age 7 to age 99 while they learn or remember everything necessary about road safety. 
In order to do so, we will be placed on a city where we will have to drive following the indications made by the local police, the visual signs, the roadmarkings, and several obstacles upon arriving at our destination.

In the game there are 8 Player Characters that form the Player Character Deck. Each turn 2 random characters are discarded and then the players secretly choose the Player Character they will play in the current turn.

Each Player Character has 2 unique abilities. The first ability may be used on any turn, however the second ability may only be used in Chapters that the Player Character appears in the book.

Secondly, we have the Story Decks which are composed of: Characters, Quotations, and Objects from the book. There are Story Decks for all 12 chapters of the book. Each card may be played for its cost in the Chapter it appears in. Character and Object cards have a Story Point value that adds to a Player's score. Quotation cards are used to complete a Chapter, which is accomplished by playing 3 cards in the appropriate Chapter, but have no Story Point value. Completed Chapters double the points scored while incomplete Chapters score only the card's combined Story Point value.

You may have noticed that I mentioned the cost of playing a card. In Alice: Adventures in Wonderland the currency we use is Tarts. One of the actions a player may take on their turn is taking Tarts. The Tarts are  used to play Story cards. Player's must carefully balance the number of Tarts they have in their possession, because at the end of the game any Tarts they have will count against their final score. They lose 1 Story Point for every Tart they did not return to the tray.

The game board we use in the game is called the Storyboard. Alice travels along a pathway from one chapter to the next, spending only a few turns in most chapters. When Alice moves into a new chapter, cards that players may have in their hands from a previous chapter may no longer be played.

Along the perimeter of the Storyboard is a Story Point Tracker. At the end of each Chapter, players score the cards they played (doubled if they played 3 cards) and all cards from the Chapter (in their hands, played in front of them, or remaining in the chapter's Story Deck) are removed from the game. There is also a Tart Tracker that represents the current number of Tarts each player has in their possession.

In the game, Alice is not a Player Character. She is not even a character in the Story Deck. In the game she is represented by a token that moves along a pathway through each chapter. She is a basically a timer. When the Alice token reaches the final space,  the game is over.

Unlucky Sevens is an extremely simple and portable game Vegas-style dice game that can be played in a very short amount of time, or over a series of rounds for a longer experience. It can be played stand-alone or as a betting or challenge game for points, rewards, or even drinks. It is simple enough for kids, but with the utility to entertain adults as well.

Players take turns rolling a pair of dice, after each roll taking a Point card corresponding to the roll made. (Even if another player has that card).

When each one of the cards finally belongs to a player, the game ends immediately and players total up their score. But beware, the 7 is Unlucky, and whoever is stuck with it will suffer a negative point penalty!

The 3-letter mystery word game.

1. Take turns being the "spy" and choosing a spy word from any card.
2. Detectives play their cards one at a time. The "spy" tells them the number of letters their words have in common with the "spy word".
3. Using their super sleuth powers of deduction, detectives narrow down the letters in common with the "spy word" with every card played.
4. The first player to guess the 3-letter mystery word wins the round!

Two thousand years ago, the Roman Empire ruled the lands around the Mediterranean Sea. With peace at the borders, harmony inside the provinces, uniform law, and a common currency, the economy thrived and gave rise to mighty Roman dynasties as they expanded throughout the numerous cities. Guide one of these dynasties and send colonists to the remote realms of the Empire; develop your trade network; and appease the ancient gods for their favor — all to gain the chance to emerge victorious!

Concordia is a peaceful, strategy game of economic development in Roman times for 2-5 players aged 13 and up. Instead of looking to the luck of dice or cards, players must rely on their strategic abilities. Be sure to watch your rivals to determine which goals they are pursuing and where you can outpace them! In the game, colonists are sent out from Rome to settle down in cities that produce bricks, food, tools, wine, and cloth. Each player starts with an identical set of playing cards and acquires more cards during the game. These cards serve two purposes:


    They allow a player to choose actions during the game.
    They are worth victory points (VPs) at the end of the game. 


Concordia is a strategy game that requires advanced planning and consideration of your opponent's moves. Every game is different, not only because of the sequence of new cards on sale but also due to the modular layout of cities. (One side of the game board shows the entire Roman Empire with 30 cities for 3-5 players, while the other shows Roman Italy with 25 cities for 2-4 players.) When all cards have been sold or after the first player builds their 15th house, the game ends. The player with the most VPs from the gods (Jupiter, Saturnus, Mercurius, Minerva, Vesta, etc.) wins the game.

In Le Petit Poucet, Tom Thumb and his brothers – after fleeing the home of the ogre – must make their way together through a mysterious forest to return to their cottage home. You must remember which places you have visited previously in order to find the right paths. Avoid the wolves, and be careful not to make too much noise or the ogre could find his way to you...

The unusual and asymmetric game Ladies & Gentlemen brings players into the world of glamour. In teams of two – one playing a man, the other a woman – the players try to pull together the best-looking and most famous couple who will attend the big ball. The gentleman's duty is to make as much money as possible, which the lady will then spend on jewelry, clothes, and exclusive accessories. Each team has its own action cards to carry out its tasks, and the more that the players embody their characters – flirtatious, fashion-obsessed ladies, and rich, arrogant, pretentious gentlemen – the more fun and explosive the game will be!

Part 1: The Valkyrie's Spear

An adventure game where players take on the role of a stranded, lady pirate on Terror Island. Cooperatively, players traverse the island, facing hazards and hunters, until the final showdown, where they will battle a villainous dog and recapture their ship.

The game is card and dice driven. It features 12 different pirates, each with a skill and a knack to differentiate them. Players will have to conserve resources, use their skills and make the right team-based choices to survive this challenging game.

Play it solitaire or with up to 6 players.

GAME-PLAY SYNOPSIS

Each pirate begins with 10 points of fortitude and one item given to them at random. With each new turn, the players (the crew) decide together if they will rest or traverse their current location.

If the crew rests, they may perform skills, such as searching for items, foraging for rations or simply resting and recovering lost fortitude.

If the crew traverses, they must each spend fortitude points to do so and then draw cards from the island deck until they reveal a new location card, at which tine the turn ends.

While drawing cards, the crew will encounter hazards from lava bursts to mischievous monkeys and possibly even pirate hunters. When hunters are encountered, the crew will do battle. Battle is a series of dice rolls used to do damage and deplete each side of its fortitude.

The goal is to reach the end of the progress track (crossing the island) and hold a final showdown with the villainous dog who stole you ship and left you stranded on Terror Island.

After their latest journey through time, the Odynauts have landed in the Stone Age. In this world, they are confronted with cavemen who revere fire above all else. Because not all cavemen have yet discovered how to make fire, some try to steal it from the others. The Odynauts see a challenging game in all of this, but being their usual selves think it would be more fun to put out an opponent's fire rather than to steal it. Can you navigate safely through enemy caves? Can your cavemen outwit their stronger opponents or overpower their weaker ones? Can you be the first to put out an opponent's fire?

Cavemen Playing With Fire is a strategic two-player card game. The goal is to be the first player to put out one of her opponent's three fires, which in game terms means taking one of the opponent's three fire cards.

To play the game, each player receives an identical deck of 25 cave, fire, and caveman cards. Players use the cave cards to create a playing field on the table with three fire cards for each player at each end. In turns, players place cards and take action. They walk and fight among their own caves and those of the enemy to try to reach one of the enemy's fire cards. The cavemen cards are ranked, and some have special abilities. Lost cards can return to the drawing deck, but to do so a player must lose certain cards first. Losing these is tricky, though.

From the publishers website and press release:

This is the first entirely new game system from ADB, Inc., in years. It brings infantry combat in the Star Fleet Universe to life in a way that allows ground battles to be fought simultaneously with the space battles portrayed by Star Fleet Battles, Federation Commander, Starmada, or A Call to Arms SF.

Over 500 unit counters portray squads of five Marines, snipers, engineers, commandos, and heavy weapons; or individual tanks and vehicles; or special game markers.

The very simple “shoot then move” system reflects the savage horror of war at bayonet point. Fast interaction is created by rules for opportunity fire and defensive snapshots, so both players are constantly acting, reacting, planning, and making hard decisions. Do you fire at those Klingon troops attacking your right flank — or hold the fire of your weapons for the main attack that has yet to appear (and might never)?

The full-color highly artistic map portrays the terrain on a typical planet far, far away, but rules allow you to designate the colored areas as crops, forest, swamps, marshes, or any of a dozen other types of alien landscape. The map even includes an active volcano and a river of lava!

Each counter is a group of five Marines (i.e., a "Boarding Party" from SFB or a "Marine squad" from FC, facilitating interactions) or a single vehicle (tank, ground combat vehicle, shuttle, or whatever). Each hex is 100 meters. While you can stack a lot of units in one hex (more infantry than vehicles, but still a lot), only a few can fire out of that hex in each direction.

The game system is one of player turns. On your turn, each of your units can either shoot or move, not both. Shooting comes first (after which the unit is turned upside down so that you remember not to move it), then movement, then you turn all of your upside down units right side up. When you shoot at an enemy unit, you cross-index the kind of unit that is shooting with the kind of unit being shot at, adjust this for any terrain that provides protection, and roll one die. The enemy unit might be destroyed, stunned (turned upside down so it won't be able to shoot or move on its next turn), or unharmed.

The first game module, SFM: Assault!, includes Marines, other infantry (commando, heavy weapons, engineers, Prime Teams, militia), and vehicles (tanks, trucks, engineer vehicles, command vehicles, and various light-armored troop carriers).

Units will be able to dig in, call for regular artillery or transporter artillery, do assault landings with shuttles or transporters, do close assaults, use opportunity fire to shoot during the enemy turn, and conduct air strikes with fighters or gunboats.

Arkham Madhouse is a card-game for 2-4 players illustrated by Pedro Belushi.

The Arkham asylums have opened their doors and their residents have escaped. They roam the city like lost souls. Your job is to bring them to the place from which they never should have left. Drive your ambulance through the streets of Arkham and find those crazy men.

And if you think this is a lame excuse to honor H. P. Lovecraft... Cthulhu will drive you mad!

On the table there is a map of Arkham formed by ten cards. The players move on the map of Arkham using the action cards. Players collect mad men cards when his pawn stays on a map card that matches the color of mad men card. Mad men cards have different values. At the end of the game the player that gets the highest score using these mad men cards is the winner.


Los manicomios de Arkham han abierto sus puertas y los residentes han escapado. Vagan por la ciudad como almas en pena. Tu trabajo es lograr que vuelvan al lugar del que nunca deberían haber salido. Conduce tu ambulancia por las calles de Akham y devuelve a los perturbados a su manicomio. Y si crees que esto es una burda excusa para homenajear a H. P. Lovecraft, que Cthulhu te arrebate la cordura para siempre.

Sobre la mesa se forma un mapa de Arkham con diez cartas. Los jugadores recorren Arkham moviendo su peón utilizando las cartas de acción. Los jugadores recogen cartas de locos cuando coincide el color de la carta de loco y de la carta de mapa sobre la que está su peón. Las cartas de loco tienen distinta puntuación. Al final del juego aquel que obtenga la máxima puntuación con las cartas de loco es el ganador.

"Aegean Fleet is a contemporary game of naval warfare taking place in Aegean Sea.
Time Scale : 
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, amphibious war ships and cargos on a map covering.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but includes new weapons as missiles, grond launched ballistic missiles, SAM, cruise missiles
There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, anti-missile defence systems, long range air-to-air missile,

The game can be linked with Arab-Israel Fleet and Black Sea Expansion

"Iron Lady’s Fleet” is a game of naval warfare taking place in South-Atlantic during the Falklands Wars in 1982.
Time Scale : 
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, amphibious war ships and cargos on a map covering.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but includes new weapons as missiles, ground launched ballistic missiles, SAM, cruise missiles
There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, anti-missile defence systems, long range air-to-air missile,

More Information:

The game includes 5 scénarios, from very simple to more complex ones :
1/  Bluff Cove Black Death
2/  Lost Cruiser
3/ Strike San Carlos
4/ Like Churchill's her fought
5/ Galtieri's Backhand Blow

Those were the days! You may well remember clogs or tight hot pants. Then you come up with a playful journey through the decade. You can expect statements about events, Zeitgeist, TV, Celebrities and Stars. For each statement, you get 3 answers. Use your memory and remember the headlines at the time or just type. Become an expert 70s?

Player with the most correct answers wins the game.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 80s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 50s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

The players alternate placing a sector former (i.e. wall) in a vertical or horizontal slot on the board.  Following placement, the player inserts one of their colored tiles into all squared sectors (i.e. a square surrounded by four sectors) and receives points for each tile placed.

Several Supergrid variations exist.  Please see the attached files for the complete set of game rules.

In Foosball players are players of two football teams and their goal is to win the game. This game is inspired by the classic foosball.

Foosball is a game for 8-22 players, aged eight years, with a variable playing time depending on what players want. It's a typical convention game for a large number of players that have a long table to sit comfortably face to face.

In each team one player will be the goalkeeper, another player will be the striker and the others will be field players. The game is divided into rounds, which end when a team scores a goal. Each round begins with a goal kick. Goalkeeper places the ball in front of him and then the goalkeeper rolls ball (rolls die). When player rolls the ball, any other player of the same team can claim the ball and the opposing team can attempt to steal the ball. If the player that has received the ball is a striker, he can shot at goal. The team that has received fewer goals is the winner


En Futbolín los jugadores forman parte de dos equipos de fútbol que se enfrentan en un partido, y su objetivo es
ganar dicho partido. Este juego está inspirado en el clásico futbolín.

Futbolín es un juego para 8-22 jugadores, mayores de ocho años, con una duración variable determinada en función de lo que los jugadores deseen. Es un típico juego de convención para un número alto de jugadores que deben disponer de una mesa larga para sentarse cómodamente frente a frente.

En cada equipo un jugador será el portero, otro el delantero y el resto jugadores de campo. El juego se divide en rondas, que concluyen cuando un equipo marca gol. En cada ronda el juego comienza con un saque de puerta. Le entregamos el dado que hace de balón al portero, que comienza el juego lanzando el dado. Una vez el dado se ha lanzado, cualquier compañero del jugador que ha lanzado puede reclamarlo, y cualquier contrario entre ambos jugadores puede robarlo. El delantero, cuando recibe el balón, puede lanzar a puerta. Gana el equipo que logra más goles.

What profession learned Erich Honecker? Which product has been sold under the brand name "Erika"?
These and similar questions must be answered in this game. 
For each question, you get 3 answers. Answer correctly and   move forward with character on the game board. 
Player who finishes first is the winner.

Motor Race game from Wolverine Supply dated 1910. Players spin a spinner and go around the track. Penalties are listed on spaces on the board. There is even a space for Tire Trouble with its own spinner to tell how many turns you lose while your tires are being fixed. You must finish the game by exact count in order to win.

Marbles? merges the exciting aspects of a party game with one-on-one challenges both observed and judged by all other players, the Peanut Gallery. Many of the challenges are reminiscent of familiar games. Others are very unique and designed specifically for the roles of Challenger, Opponent and Peanut Gallery. Marble-like gems are the currency. Players must use their intellectual marbles to win challenges and also strategically pose challenges that are to their greatest advantage. Highly dimensional, there are multiple perspectives of strategy.

Players take turns being the Challenger and can select any player not previously an Opponent in the same round. "Teaser" cards indicate Opponent availability. Opponent cards change the dynamics of the challenge. Peanut Gallery cards permit side wagers, further expanding the dimensions of how the game is played.

All challenges are performed in (2) minutes or less. Challenger cards detail a wide variety of tasks across (7) categories:
1) Consensus - The Peanut Gallery is polled to derive a count that the opponent must accurately predict. Some are factual events like visiting an ATM within the last 24 hours while others are preferences such as: Cat or Dog, Chocolate or Vanilla, Paper or Plastic…
2) Dice - Challenger cards in this category require a specified outcome from the roll of dice. Luck over skill, the tasks vary as defined for each challenge.
3) Domino – To win, the Opponent must also hold a Challenger card in this category having a Domino number that matches one of the two numbers presented by the Challenger.
4) Performance – Opponent must skillfully complete the challenge. Examples include telling a joke that invokes laughter and an impersonation in which the Peanut Gallery must correctly guess.
5) Physical – Another skill category, the Opponent must successfully complete a task involving an activity like Origami (paper folding) or Roshambo (Rock-Paper-Scissors).  When the results are subjective, the Peanut Gallery judges the task.
6) Playing Cards – A single hand of a common card game is played, such as Blackjack or Draw Poker. Every Challenger card in this category fully defines the task and specifies the requirements necessary to win.
7) Starter – Cards in this category quickly establish the winner, simply with who holds the highest number.

The objective is simple. Take turns matching a Challenger card in hand with an opponent anticipated least likely to successfully complete the task. Opponents set the wager, either (1) or (2) marbles, upon the Challenger announcing the category. Should the Opponent fail the task, the Challenger wins the wager. Otherwise, the Opponent collects the wager.  Number of players determines the number of rounds. At game end after the final showdown (in case of a tie, if necessary), the player with the most marbles reigns supreme.

Not at all the game of marbles everyone played as a child, this version is all grown up but still retains the youthful retro spirit.
"Wanna play Marbles?"

180 Marbles? Cards, 4 Color-Coded Types, 7 Challenger Categories

Here the women are playing against the men, and vice versa. Do you know how many cylinders a Porsche 911 has? Or is the material from which the best nail file? These and similar questions must be answered here. Depending on the game type questions are asked of others and / or the same sex. The players love one estimate, if the question can be answered correctly or not. Who know a lot or can bluff well is rapidly advancing on the board and win this battle of the sexes - at least temporarily!

Business hours in English allows the player to get into the business manager role, reflecting the business processes.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get the most traditional customer base, or the highest market share.

In his turn player can generete experience of his company  by searching customers or buy and sale products. 
When they have loyal customer, when products are offered for sale, they can make even the highest prices.
Two players can at any time join forces in order to reduce market competition and displace opponents. In this case, players combine business with all their resources: both players money, privileges, raw materials and traditional customer base, but the experience can not be combined.

This was a really old 'Roll and Move' boardgame, the estimated date of publication is somewhere between 1890 and 1913.

The original print is kept at the Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington, D.C.

Unlike other word games, the objective of Perfect Word is to derive the single word that best matches (4) types of criteria. Roll (12) dice, draw one Perfect Word card and start the 2-minute timer. Use as many point letters as possible, including non-point letters as needed. Perfect Word cards permit one helpful exception, such as unlimited license to use the letter "P".

Word games are more fun when there is a challenging twist. The longest words are not necessarily the Perfect Word. One point is deducted for every syllable. If the required letters are available, "squirreled" is a Perfect Word. It contains (10) letters but only has (1) syllable.

Absorb your enemy, but don't get eaten by a Grue. An abstract strategy game for Looney pyramids of capture and maneuver.

From the Icehousegames.org background:
"Battles on the savage gleeb homeworld are fought in deadly arenas. Two groups of gleebs enter, each aiming to absorb the enemy before meeting that grisly fate themselves. Further adding to the excitement are three ravenous grues who have their own plan for the gleebs..."

Each player takes 2 colors of pyramids, while the black pyramids represent Grues. On their turn, players move one of their pyramids onto a pyramid of a different color, and then must move a black pyramid, potentially immobilizing or removing pyramids from the game, even their own.

The player who controls the most pips worth of pyramids at the end of the game wins.

Requires a 4x4 playing board and 1 Treehouse stash:
3 blue pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 red pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 yellow pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 green pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 black pyramids in small, medium, and large
for a total of 15 pyramids.

In this game players use the four basic arithmetic operations. The aim of the game is, with at least three of the dice to calculate the numbers on the previously required results from the drawn cards.

The card is drawn the dice are rolled and the quickest player socres a point.

The game contains 3300 questions and answer choices from the varied experience and experience range from pre-school children.
In his turn player rolls the die and draws a card where the question is read according to die roll. There are four possible answers for each question. Player gets the card if the answer is correct.

At the end of the game the player with the most cards is the winner.

Help to help in English.
Players are volunteers who try to help and support people who need clothes, food, medicine, work or money.
In his turn player roll the dice and move up to 4 volunteers of his team on the game board to search sponsors and needed resources. If then player is able to support one or more people/organizations he scores a point for every such act.

Player who have the most points by supporting at the end of the game is the winner.

The game consists of tiles showing postage stamps. The tiles are shuffled and placed on the table in a grid, leaving some spaces free. Each player gets a secret collector's interest tile, showing which kind of stamps s/he collects. 
In a turn, the active player picks up a tile, shows it to everyone and places it facedown in one of the free spaces in the grid. This continues until all tiles have been flipped over. In subsequent turns, a player can either swap two facedown tiles, move a facedown tile to an empty space or flip open a tile, putting it back to where it was. 
When a player thinks that there are five stamps of his/her field of interest in a row, s/he flips these open to check. If correct, points are scored. Other players get as many points as "their" tiles are in a row as well. 
The player who scored most points after a certain number of rounds is the winner.

Armis is a two player high-strategy board game, your objective is to capture the opponent's flag.  Success is achieved by planning, implementing, and assessing various strategies and tactics given specific rules, resources, and environments.

Armis rules are detailed in the Player’s Handbook; the game has three environments: land, air, and sea;  and the 17 resources are: Flag, President, Vice President, Army, Aircraft Carrier, Submarine, Jet, Helicopter, Marines, Coast Guard, Reserve, Diplomat, Religion, Child, Mover, Media, and Nuke.

Given the above, players instinctively and continuously formulate offensive and defensive situations until a winner emerges.

Armis is great exercise for the mind, and the brain.

Questions about dogs - puppies, care, breeds, diseases, dog sports, origin, education, dog owners, breeding, and dog foods.

6 question on card with 3 answer choises for each question, the question is determined rolling the dice. Depending on the version you have to collect a small plate of each color or get rid of the flakes.

Objective:
be the first climbing up victory points list to the top
- moving/acting by turn -

each player throws the die, moving round the board, drafting cards (some multiple choice), finding questions for answers out the 60's - 90's, gaining victory points.

Contents:

     1 game board with two game plans
     55 quiz cards with 6600 questions and answers
     4 Betting Chips
     36 Number of chips
     1 dice
     4 game characters
     1 set of instructions

The friends Franz von Hahn, Johnny Mauser and Waldemar see each other through a lot of adventures. In Variant 1 a players rolls the die to determine the number of tries he has to find a certain tile, depending on what he turns up the turn stone or the player’s stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins. In variant 2 correct tiles are placed on the board, all players win together when all tiles are on the board and the turn stone is not over the finish. In Variant 3 the players piece is moved, then tiles are searched and depending on the result the player’s piece or the turn stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

Players are managers of one or more boxers by training and sending them a ring, winning advertising contracts and negotiating the profit exchanges.
There is also possible to bet to boxers You think to win.

The ranking is determined by dice the fighting with the boxing cards and boxing dice.

The game is played over an entire season, the victory decide the highest revenue.

Players are collecting interesting themes for the next show in the series, there are 6 categories - Space, Dinosaurs, Technology, Underwater, Nature and Man. On the board theme- and action cards are randomly distributed. In his turn a player must answer a question from one of the 6 categories. If his answer is correct, he may move up to three spaces, if his answer is wrong, he moves one space. If his move ends on a space with a card, the player may turn the card over - if he can use it for one of his themes, he can take it. If it is an action card, he can use it immediately or later in the game. The player who gathers his 4 themes for the show first, wins the game..

Two opposing fleets of 5 ships each, one fleet being blue and the other red vie to see which fleet can capture all the ships of the other.
A die roll determines which fleet begins in Cadiz and which fleet begins in the Tortugas.
Players use a spinner to determine how far to move. That movement can be in any direction over GOLD roads or over the roads of his/her color. The winner is the player having any ships left, after all of the ships of the enemy have been captured.
Gold roads can be used by any player. Red cannot use Blue roads and vice versa. Any ship that arrives at the enemy headquarters captures all of the ships there. If there are no ships there the player gets back one of his own ships or the first ship subsequently captured afterwards. That ship begins again in his home area. To capture a ship it must be landed on by exact count. There are mines that might be landed on. These destroy ships which are permanently removed from the game

From NY Historical Museum: 
"The Game of Naval War" paper covered cardboard box top with a chromolithographed image of a naval battle with a gun deck in the foreground with crew members dying and ships in the background sinking and burning and two American ships coming to the rescue; cover inscribed, "THE/ GAME/ OF/ NAVAL WAR/ COPYRIGHT 1898/ McLOUGHLIN BROS/ NEW YORK/ COPYRIGHT 1898 BY F. D. MAHER."

Overall: 13 x 21 1/2 in. ( 33 x 54.6 cm )

bodyIQ - Premium is a game about the body, how it works, how to improve it and physical exercises.

Basically it a trivia game with a twist. There are 12 categories. 10 based on some of the bodys most important organs, 1 health check and 1 physical excersise, 600 questions/task all in all. Each turn the player roll the die, and moves his marker along the paths of the body. Depending on the space the player ends on, he will either get a question, a health check or a physical task to do. If he answers correct, or performs the task, he will win the card, giving him a number of years.

For younger players there is a multriple choise option.

There are three suggestend ways to end the game:
1) Play until one player reaches 100 years.
2) Play until one player collects all 12 categories.
3) Play for a certaing amount of time.
Whoever has the most points (=years) at the end of the game wins.

A card game played with a standard 52-card deck and a mat that outline potential card plays.  Players take turns placing cards out on the display mat, scoring melds of 3 cards as they do.  On a single card play, it's possible to play two melds, with face cards acting as multipliers.

In the card game Flame War, each player takes the role of a forum admin. Starting threads, posting, flaming, maybe some trolling, and perhaps even bringing up a certain pony that might in fact be little and belong to someone you know...

Flame War is a fun and clever game about running a forum. Every card in the game represents a post made by a forum member, often directed at another member. Some are informational, some are random, and some are downright mean. The internet is a scary place for folks who like to read what other people write. Closing down threads scores you points, and the player who scores the most points when the game ends wins.

Game consists of 10 numbered dice and two spotted dice.

In a turn, the ten numbered dice are thrown and then the two spotted dice. From the ten dice you may take any number of them that total the number rolled with the spotted dice.
i.e. you roll 9 with the spotted dice: you can now take away any combination of the numbered dice that add up to 9.
If successful, you throw again, and so on.

When you cannot take way the number rolled, the total of the remaing dice are added together and that is your score.

The player with the lowest score after an agreed number of rounds, wins.

Game description from the publisher:

Long ago, in the ancient city of the Mayan empire, nine temples were built with different stone blocks, but the blocks were all mixed up!

Luckily, great priests held the knowledge of powerful magic, and they can rebuild the towers without damaging them. Now they compete to create nine single-colored towers by exchanging the massive blocks of stone between them. If one of them can join the colored stones together, he will earn the right to decorate the tower with his own ladder. And if he can build an entire tower in a single color he will earn a special reward: His followers alone will forever greet the sun from the top of the tower!

In Maya, as one of these mighty priests, can you outwit your opponents and rerrange the stones of the nine towers?

Game description from the publisher:

In those far-off days when people had already ceased to live on the trees, but did not yet know how to make cars, the main occupation of men was hunting. Neither mighty mammoth, nor nosy ground squirrel – indeed, not any animal could escape the watchful eyes of experienced hunters.

In Jabba-Dabba-Dû!, you'll become the chief hunter of a tribe and go to the hunting grounds as the head of the mighty men. Get the most thick and tasty mammoth, and bring it to your women. But beware as your tribe in not the only one on these plains – and these frail parodies of men consider themselves hunters, too! Prove that it's not true! Leave them behind in pursuit of the prey!

The players are fighting over 5 hunting locations. Each turn, you select two cards, playing them face down until they are revealed to the group. The cards are the 5 hunting locations while the 6th card is another caveman hunter, allowing you to double up at that location. The cards are revealed and you transfer your cavemen figures to the marker. Each turn there is a winner at the hunting ground based on the highest number of cavemen there. The winner gets the highest number of victory points, which varies from hunting location to hunting location. The player with the most points wins!

This hand-management card game is a rummy variant that is themed on the Richie Rich comic book character. The deck consist of 36 cards, 2 each of 18 professions, ranging from Hobo to Skywriter to Doctor. After dealing the shuffled cards to the players, the first player draws a card from the person to her right. She then lays down all matched pairs in her hand. Play continues to the left. The last player to have a card in her hand wins.

This is a simple game in which players spin A spinner to collect Colorform pieces that correspond to their player mat. The game comes with two sets of Colorforms that depict characters from the Where's Waldo Now book. The Colorforms are placed randomly on the spinner at the start of the game. Each turn, a player spins the spinner and can collect a Colorform from the quadrant of the spinner that the arrow points to provided the sticker matches their player mat. The first player to collect all four characters for their mat wins.

Unusual word game. Each guest is given a sheet of twelve statements about words. Half will get an Oxford sheet, the other half a Cambridge sheet.

The Oxford sheet answers are all words using the letters in the word 'Oxford'. The Cambridge sheet answers are all words using the letters in the word 'Cambridge'.

After time runs out, the guest with the most right answers, wins.
